dialogs.name: fallenDetailFilter
html: Filter by selecting one or more criteria and click Apply.
The website has remembered your Filtered criteria from your previous visit; to cancel these, click Reset.
Location of Memorial or Cemetery (all)

dialogs.name: filter-age
html: Filter by age or ages from the list below, and click Apply.
You need to select at least one age.
Your filter selection results in an empty list, please re-select or close the dialogue.

dialogs.name: filterHelp
html: Use the Filter Form to make browsing the Roll of Honour more specific.
Each of the fallen has nine criteria to filter by: Rank, Age, Regiment, Street, Date of Death, Memorial, Cemetery, Location, Tag. The Filter
Form has a button for each of these, which when clicked will display a list of relevant choices from which you can specify your selection.
For example, to find all the fallen who served in Canadian regiments, click the Regiment button; Clear All; and click the three Canadian
regiments listed; scroll down to the bottom of the list and click the Select button.
You can also filter on multiple criteria. To find all the fallen who served in Canadian regiments and whose names are on the Ypres memorial;
click the Regiment button to select the Canadian regiments; and the memorial button to select the Ypres memorial.
Once you have entered the selection criteria, click the Filter button to return to the detail page, where you�ll see the names of the fallen
who match your filter criteria; the full details of the first person in the list are also displayed.
To make further changes to your filter criteria click the Filter List button again, your previous filter criteria will still be displayed.
The filter form also has a Reset button to reset the selection criteria to �All�.
We will continue to update and refine the filter function as the site evolves.

dialogs.name: MapHelp
html: This Help box is automatically displayed the first time you visit the map page. To see it again click Help on the menu below the map.
To view the map, close the box.

We have used a map of the period to pinpoint the home addresses of the Fallen of Ulverston, as many of the streets do not now exist. The map is from the National Library of Scotland, many thanks to them.
However, of the 175 Ulverston fallen, 29 of them do not have an address that appears on the map, all those that do are marked with a poppy.
When you filter the fallen, there are three possibilities: all, some, or none of the selected names will have an address indicated on the map.
Text above the map tells you whether all, some or none have been displayed, and whether the fallen have been filtered to your selection.
This page is known as the fallen map page, and is not the only way to view and filter the fallen.
We also have a page that presents the fallen as a list, it is known as the fallen list page.
Below the map, there is a link to take you to the fallen list page.
On the fallen list page there is a link to return you to this page. As you jump from one page to the other, your filter criteria will be remembered and actioned.
The fallen list page can be used to see all of the fallen for your filter criteria, including those that do not appear on the map
For example, if you filter on the three Canadian regiments, there are eight fallen, but only six appear on the map.
If you go to the fallen list page, you can view all of them.
On the fallen map page you can only see the six that appear on the map.
Occasionally, no fallen appear on the map. An example of this is when you filter on the tag named 'Brothers Ibison'.
